In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) (2009) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), 
approved by the Board of Directors in July 2009 and effective since January 2010, is the result 
of an extensive consultation process with governments, civil society organizations (CSOs), the 
private sector, and academia from ADB's member countries. A key policy feature, the SPS 
emphasizes  ADB's  responsibility  to  assist  developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in 
strengthening their own safeguard systems and in enhancing their implementation capacity to 
address environmental and social issues. This technical assistance (TA) is designed to support 
the  strengthening  and  effective  implementation  of  country  safeguard  systems  (CSS).1 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  In  2008,  ADB  adopted  Strategy  2020,2 which  focuses  its  operations  on  promoting 
environmentally sustainable and inclusive economic growth. Strategy 2020 embraces a set of 
six corporate-wide core values, including recognition of country ownership to enable DMCs to 
exercise effective leadership over development policies, strategies, and actions. Further, ADB's 
operational goals include meeting all major commitments under the 2005 Paris Declaration on 
Aid Effectiveness3 by the agreement’s target of 2012 through partnerships with its DMCs and 
other development agencies.  
 
3.  The Accra Agenda for Action in 2008 strongly reiterated the commitments under Paris 
Declaration  and  called  for  specific  actions  to  strengthen  and  increase  the  use  of  country 
systems. As pointed out in a 2010 report, since it endorsed the Accra Agenda for Action in 2008, 
ADB has made considerable progress in carrying out its responsibilities for (i) strengthening 
country ownership; (ii) building more effective, inclusive partnerships; and (iii) delivering and 
accounting for development results, and will seek greater aid and development effectiveness by 
promoting DMC ownership of the development agenda at the country level and by forming more 
productive, inclusive partnerships to influence aid effectiveness policy at the international level.4 
 
4.  The SPS arrived at a critical time, as ADB scales up its assistance to DMCs in promoting 
environmentally sustainable and inclusive economic growth through Strategy 2020, and as it 
continues to focus on improving aid and development effectiveness in Asia and the Pacific. The 
SPS builds upon ADB’s Environment Policy (2002), Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995), and 
Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998) to enhance their effectiveness and to ensure that the 
policies remain relevant to DMCs' changing needs. The SPS also better harmonizes the policies 
with current and emerging international best practices among multilateral development banks 
and private sector financial institutions, such as the Equator Principles.  
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB website on 3 June 2010.  
2  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.  
3 The major commitments of donors under Paris Declaration are: (i) respect partner country leadership and help 
strengthen their capacity to exercise it; (ii) base donors overall support on partner countries' national development 
strategies, institutions, and procedures; (iii) harmonize actions among donors;; (iv) manage resources and improve 
decision-making for results; (v) and provide partner countries timely, transparent, and comprehensive information 
on aid flows. These commitments apply to financial management, procurement, and environmental and social 
safeguards. 
4  ADB. 2010. Aid Effectiveness Report. Manila.

2   
5.  Among the many important elements of the SPS is its emphasis on assisting DMCs to 
strengthen and implement their own CSS—an objective that goes well beyond the benefits of 
increasing the use of CSS to satisfy the environmental and social safeguard requirements of 
donor-supported projects and programs. Strengthened CSS will enhance DMC ownership and 
benefit all projects regardless of source of funding, including those undertaken by a DMC 
without any international development agencies' support or supervision.  
 
6.  In the last two decades, DMCs have developed their own systems regarding safeguards 
for the environment, involuntary resettlement, and Indigenous Peoples to varying degrees. In 
some DMCs, the legal frameworks have been well established, but implementation remains 
weak due to inadequate institutional capacity, financial shortfalls, and/or lack of meaningful 
public participation and transparency. In others, legal frameworks are inadequate and require 
significant improvement. Experience gained through ongoing ADB TA for strengthening country 
safeguard systems 5 and that of the World Bank on the use of borrower systems in addressing 
environmental and social safeguard issues suggest that (i) the effectiveness of development 
agencies' safeguard policies depends largely on the degree to which the safeguard policy 
principles and requirements are rooted in DMCs' culture and socioeconomic context of decision 
making, (ii) development agencies can increase the impact of their development assistance if 
they  support  efforts  to  strengthen  and  work  more  directly  with  DMCs’  existing  legal  and 
governance  frameworks  and  institutions,  (iii)  strategies  and  approaches  for  supporting  the 
strengthening and effective implementation of CSS should be adapted to meet different DMCs 
needs, (iv) CSS diagnostic studies are a useful tool for helping DMCs identify the areas for CSS 
strengthening and develop action plans to address the gaps, and (v) development agencies 
need to work toward greater cooperation in engaging in efforts for the strengthening and use of 
CSS. 
 
7.  In recognition of these suggestions, the SPS commits ADB to expanding its engagement 
with  DMCs  in  strengthening  their  ownership  and  enhancing  their  capacity  to  address 
environmental and social safeguards through a long-term programmatic effort. It also calls for 
pursuing  this  effort  with  other  development  agencies  within  the  framework  of  the  Paris 
Declaration  and  Accra  Agenda  for  Action.  The  proposed  TA  is  designed  to  support  the 
strengthening and effective implementation of CSS in DMCs. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced environmental and social sustainability of DMC 
development projects, regardless of their source of funding. The outcome will be strengthened 
CSS through one or more of the following areas in each participating DMC: 
(i)   improved legal and regulatory frameworks for environmental assessment and 
management, involuntary resettlement, and/or Indigenous Peoples; 
(ii)   strengthened  institutions  and  capacity  for  effective  implementation  and 
enforcement  of  and  compliance  with  laws  and  regulations  pertaining  to 
environmental  assessment  and  management,  involuntary  resettlement  and/or 
Indigenous Peoples safeguards; 
(iii)   enhanced  state-owned  and/or  private  sector  companies'  environmental  and 
social management systems; 
                                                 
5  ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems. Manila (TA 6285-REG, for 
$800,000, approved 12 December).

3
(iv)   enhanced programs for public awareness and involvement in the environmental 
and social assessment, planning, and implementation process; 
(v)   improved  mechanisms  for  information  sharing,  knowledge  management,  and 
dissemination; 
(vi)   action  plans  for  CSS  strengthening  at  national,  sector,  and/or  agency  level 
developed  for  and  adopted  by  governments  or  private  sector  companies  for 
implementation; and 
(vii)  enhanced  cooperation  among  development  agencies  for  long-term  programs 
with funding sources available for strengthening and effective implementation of 
CSS.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.   Output  1: Subproject  implementation. The TA will help ADB provide systematic, 
timely support for subprojects tailored to the needs of specific DMCs for strengthening and 
effective implementation of their respective CSS. The subprojects will be proposed, prepared 
and administered by ADB departments concerned. In allocating the TA resources, priority will be 
given to  
(i)  legal  and  regulatory  framework,  rules,  and/or  procedures  on  environmental 
assessment  and  management, 6  involuntary  resettlement,  and  Indigenous 
Peoples safeguards; 
(ii)  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  development  of  relevant  government 
institutions or agencies, CSOs, and/or other stakeholder groups to implement, 
enforce,  and  comply  with  national  laws  and  regulations  on  environmental 
assessment  and  management,  involuntary  resettlement,  and  Indigenous 
Peoples;7 
(iii)  state-owned  and/or  private  sector  companies'  environmental  and  social 
management systems;8 
(iv)  public  awareness  and  participation  in  environmental  and  social  assessment, 
planning, and implementation processes; 
(v)  targeted  training  programs  and/or  studies  on  environmental  and  social 
safeguards for governments including the judiciary, CSOs, media, academia, 
and/or other stakeholder groups; and 
(vi)  demonstration  activities  (“South-South  initiatives",  such  as  through  twinning 
arrangements). 
 
10.  Open to all DMCs, the subprojects will be fully in line with and supportive of DMCs' 
priorities identified in their development plans and programs and with ADB's country partnership 
strategies. They will be complementary but will not substitute nor duplicate ADB ongoing or 
pipeline activities (i.e., the TA will not finance activities that are normally financed by project 
preparatory TA work or by other funds managed by ADB, including the Japan Special Fund). 
They will also balance the use of international and national consultants, and emphasize the 
transfer of international experience and knowledge to governments, CSOs, and staff of other 
domestic organizations in the participating DMC. Each subproject will not exceed $250,000, and

11.  Output  2:  Knowledge  management  and  dissemination.  Activities  under  this 
component  will  include  CSS  diagnostic  studies,9 conferences,  reports,  publications,  and 
knowledge  exchange  and  dissemination  through  existing  and  well-functioning  regional 
network(s).  
 
12.  Output 3: Coordination among development agencies. Through the TA, ADB will 
coordinate with other development agencies in supporting and mobilizing resources toward CSS 
capacity development activities. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $5,000,000 equivalent, financed on a grant basis 
from  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).10 Detailed  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  TA subprojects will be proposed, prepared and implemented by operations departments, 
resident missions, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD), or the Office of 
General  Counsel  (OGC)  as  relevant.  Governments,  CSOs,  state-owned  or  private  sector 
companies, academia, and other stakeholder groups in participating DMCs can also propose 
activities through these ADB departments.  
 
15.  A steering committee, comprising representatives of operations departments, OGC, and 
RSDD will have overall oversight responsibilities of the TA. The committee will review and 
approve subproject proposals, and provide strategic direction for TA implementation. Selection 
of subprojects will be based on the funding priorities (para. 9) and principles and criteria (para. 
10). To be eligible to participate in TA activities, DMCs will be requested to endorse the TA and 
appoint a focal point. No funds will be disbursed until an approval or no-objection letter for the 
approved subproject is secured from the DMC government concerned.  
 
16.  The Environment and Safeguards Division (RSES) of RSDD will be responsible for 
coordinating  with  the  ADB  departments  concerned  on  the  identification,  processing,  and 
implementation of TA activities. The RSES team will be responsible for (i) preparing subproject 
proposal  guidelines  and  formats;  (ii)  coordinating  the  proposal  preparation,  review,  and 
selection process; (iii) screening proposals for eligibility; (iv) establishing and maintaining a 
monitoring  system  of  approved  TA  activities;  (v)  implementing  knowledge  dissemination 
activities; (vi) conducting review missions for selected subprojects; and (vii) preparing annual TA 
reports and a final report. The RSES team will work with ADB Department of External Relations 
to manage and disseminate knowledge products, and collaborate with regional network(s) to 
enhance  synergy  and  co-host  workshops.  The  RSES  team  will  work  with  the  Office  of

17.  ADB will recruit consultants to carry out subproject activities and to assist with TA 
coordination and administration in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). For TA coordination, administration, and CSS diagnostic 
studies, individual consultants will be recruited including (i) 30 person-months of international 
consultants as technical advisors for overall TA administration, knowledge product preparation 
and  dissemination,  as  well  as  for  coordination  and  cooperation  with  other  development 
agencies; (ii) 9 person-months of international legal expert(s) for CSS diagnostic studies, and (ii) 
72 person-months of national consultants for TA coordination and administration and CSS 
diagnostic studies. For subproject implementation, ADB departments concerned will prepare 
terms of reference and cost estimates, and will hire the necessary consultants.  
 
18.  The equipment and materials to be provided under TA will be procured in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Equipment 
purchased for subproject implementation becomes the property of the implementing agency or 
CSO after the subproject completion. Disbursement under the TA will be done in accordance 
with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
19.  Subproject  implementation  will  be  monitored  through  inception,  midterm,  and  final 
reviews  by  the  ADB  departments  concerned,  as  required.  These  departments  will  be 
responsible for ensuring quality and consistency in the proposals, supervising implementation, 
and reporting progress to RSES on a periodic basis. Annual progress reports will also be 
prepared by RSES.  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 3.5 years, from July 2010 to December 2013.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
21.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  the  provision  of  a  technical 
assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis for Strengthening and 
Use of Country Safeguard Systems.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.   Technical Assistance Advisers (30 person-months, international) 
 
1.  The main responsibilities of the consultant(s) will be to (i) provide technical advice and 
support in the overall implementation of the technical assistance (TA) on Strengthening and Use 
of  Country  Safeguard  Systems  (CSS);  (ii)  synthesize  lessons  learned,  compile  related 
knowledge products, and provide technical support for knowledge dissemination; (iii) provide 
technical  support  to  CSS  diagnostic  studies;  and  (iv)  help  coordinate  CSS  strengthening 
activities among development partners and mobilize additional resources. Consultant(s) will be 
hired on an individual basis. The consultants will undertake the following tasks: 
(i)  prepare  guidelines  for  subproject  review,  selection,  and  monitoring  and 
evaluation, with the TA administration coordinators; 
(ii)  support officers of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in charge of subproject 
preparation and implementation as well as the team from ADB Environment and 
Safeguard  Division  (RSES)  in  the  preparation,  review,  and  selection  of 
subproject  proposals  for  possible  funding,  with  the  TA  administration 
coordinators; 
(iii)  coordinate with and support the ADB officers in charge of subproject preparation 
and implementation in managing knowledge and lessons learned, and prepare 
knowledge products for each subproject in a consistent manner; 
(iv)  synthesize  experience  and  knowledge  gained  from  the  implementation  of 
subprojects; 
(v)  provide support in monitoring and evaluating subprojects; 
(vi)  prepare guidelines on methodologies for conducting CSS diagnostics based on 
ADB and the World Bank's experiences; 
(vii)  provide support to the preparation of CSS diagnostic studies (including both 
equivalent and acceptability assessments), help design and organize in-country 
consultations, and participate in the consultations as resource persons; 
(viii)  synthesize experience and knowledge gained from the studies and consultations, 
and prepare knowledge products; 
(ix)  design the knowledge management and dissemination program and activities, 
with the TA administration coordinators; 
(x)  provide  support  in  organizing  and  participate  in  country  and/or  regional 
workshops, with the TA administration coordinators; 
(xi)  assist the RSES team in coordinating other development partners to support 
CSS strengthening activities and in mobilizing financial resources from bilateral 
and  multilateral  financing  institutions  for  long-term  safeguards  capacity 
development; 
(xii)  prepare documents for donor cooperation; 
(xiii)  prepare TA reports, with the TA administration coordinators; and  
(xiv)  conduct other relevant and reasonable tasks as required. 
 
B.   Legal Expert(s) (9 person-months, international) 
 
2.  For participating developing member countries (DMCs) where CSS diagnostic studies 
are required, the international legal expert(s) will carry out the following tasks under supervision 
of ADB Office of General Counsel (OGC): 
(i)  provide guidance to national legal experts for data collection, compilation, and 
analysis to determine equivalence between the CSS and ADB's safeguard policy;

12   Appendix 3 
(ii)  review applicable constitution, all laws, decrees, circulars, mandatory technical 
requirements,  and  any  relevant  environmental  and  social  safeguard 
jurisprudence; 
(iii)  review reports prepared by national lawyers; 
(iv)  collect and review relevant reports prepared by ADB and other international 
organizations, including country environmental analysis reports and equivalence 
assessment reports prepared by the World Bank; 
(v)  visit participating DMCs and hold meetings/discussions with governments and 
other stakeholders, where required; 
(vi)  based on (i) to (v), draft equivalence assessment report in accordance with 
ADB's guidelines on methodologies for conducting CSS diagnostics; 
(vii)  based on the results of the equivalence assessments, identify and recommend  
any specific actions relating to formal policies, laws, regulations, or related rules 
that are needed for the relevant DMC; 
(viii)  help design and participate in in-country consultation workshop for equivalence 
assessment as resource person; and 
(ix)  assist operations departments concerned, OGC, and RSES finalize equivalence 
assessment report based on the in-country consultation results and ADB staff's 
comments. 
 
C.  Country  Safeguard  Specialists  (30  person-months,  including  at  least  12  person-
months for experts with legal backgrounds, national) 
 
3.  Experts in environment, involuntary resettlement, and Indigenous Peoples laws and 
implementation will be engaged on an individual basis to undertake the following tasks in 
cooperation with the TA advisers in charge of CSS diagnostic studies:  
(i)  assist  in  collecting  data  (including  compiling  national  laws,  regulations,  and 
standards, and data on host country's practices, track records, and institutional 
capacity  through  field  visit,  interviews,  and  secondary  data  collection)  and 
conduct data analysis for CSS diagnostics studies; 
(ii)  assist in drafting equivalence assessment reports; 
(iii)  assist in drafting acceptability assessment reports; 
(iv)  coordinate and organize country consultation workshops, and participate in the 
workshops as resource persons; and 
(v)  assist in updating the assessment reports based on the consultation results. 
 
D.  Technical Assistance Administration Coordinators (42 person-months, national) 
 
4.  The consultants will be engaged on an individual basis to support TA coordination, TA 
monitoring,  and  knowledge  management.  Specifically,  the  consultants  will  undertake  the 
following tasks: 
(i)  assist  the  RSES  team  in  coordinating  TA  operations  across  relevant  ADB 
departments; preparing guidelines and procedures for subproject proposal review, 
selection, monitoring, and evaluation; reviewing subproject concept papers and 
proposals  for  possible  funding  under  the  TA;  coordinating  the  work  of 
international and national TA consultants; preparing and managing workshops; 
setting up and administering a monitoring system for the TA; and preparing TA 
progress reports and the final report; 
(ii)  assist in designing the knowledge management and dissemination program and 
activities;  update  and  maintain  ADB's  safeguards  website;  and  assist  in

Appendix 3  13 
developing  knowledge  products  based  on  outcomes  of  subproject 
implementation, diagnostic studies, and outputs of other TA activities; and 
(iii)  assist in financial resources mobilization activities by liaising with bilateral and 
multilateral  financial  institutions,  including  document  preparation,  information 
dissemination, and meeting arrangement. 
 
E.  International and National Consultants for Subproject Implementation 
 
5.  Based  on  developing  member  countries'  specific  needs,  various  ADB  operations 
departments, the Regional and Sustainable Development Department, and OGC as relevant will 
prepare the terms of reference for international and national consultants to implement country 
and subregional subprojects that will be selected and funded under the TA.
